title: Could your brain repair itself? - Ralitsa Petrova

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential reality that scientists are investigating right now?

options.label: A
options.text: That the brain can only self-organize into different structures.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: That the brain can only produce new neurons during embryonic development.

options.label: D
options.text: That the brain can only repair itself through stem cell transplantation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which adult brains produce new cells in at least three specialized locations?

options.label: A
options.text: The cerebral cortex, the cerebellum, and the brainstem.

options.label: B
options.text: The dentate gyrus, the subventricular zone, and the striatum.

options.label: C
options.text: The hippocampus, the amygdala, and the hypothalamus.

options.label: D
options.text: The olfactory bulb, the visual cortex, and the auditory cortex.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of neural stem cells and progenitor cells in neurogenesis?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce new neurons or replace old ones.

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the growth and development of the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: To respond to injuries and diseases in the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: To transmit signals between different parts of the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the promising possible approaches to harnessing neurogenesis to get the brain to heal its scars?

options.label: A
options.text: Administering certain proteins and other small molecules to the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: Transplanting healthy human neural stem cells to injured tissue.

options.label: C
options.text: Using gene therapy to modify brain cells.

options.label: D
options.text: Using electroencephalography to monitor brain activity.

multiple-choice.question: What is another possible approach to harnessing neurogenesis to get the brain to heal its scars?

options.label: A
options.text: Teaching other kinds of brain cells, such as astrocytes or oligodendrocytes, to behave like neural stem cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Using stem cell transplantation to replace damaged brain tissue.

options.label: C
options.text: Administering certain proteins and small molecules to the brain to make neural stem cells produce more neurons.

options.label: D
options.text: Using gene therapy to modify brain cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of regenerative medicine in relation to neurogenesis?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the wiring behind the brain's biological motherboard.

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new treatments for neurological diseases.

options.label: C
options.text: To harness neurogenesis to get the brain to heal its scars.

options.label: D
options.text: To study the behavior of brain cells.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The challenge of teaching other kinds of brain cells to behave like neural stem cells.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: It causes them to gel into a solid mass.

options.label: D
options.text: It causes them to become stuck in tangled up aggregates.

options.label: B
options.text: They can remain in their solid state.

options.label: D
options.text: They can become stuck in tangled up aggregates.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key part of the process that allows the proteins to snap back into their native shapes?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: It can be used to produce new drugs more quickly and cheaply.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be used to create new types of proteins.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be used to refold proteins that are stuck in tangled up aggregates.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: The Maillard reaction is a type of cooking process that is similar to boiling an egg.

options.label: D
options.text: The Maillard reaction is a type of cooking process that is harder to undo than boiling an egg.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential limitation of this unboiling method?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It may not work with all types of proteins.

options.label: D
options.text: It may not work with proteins that are stuck in tangled up aggregates.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to refold the protein.

options.label: C
options.text: It prevents the protein from becoming stuck in tangled up aggregates.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the protein.

options.label: A
options.text: It can be used to produce new drugs more quickly and cheaply.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be used to create new types of proteins.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be used to refold proteins that are stuck in tangled up aggregates.

options.label: D
options.text: It can be used to create new types of medications.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of positively charged protons.

title: Learning from smallpox: How to eradicate a disease - Julie Garon and Walter A. Orenstein

multiple-choice.question: What is the story of smallpox, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The story of a disease that was eradicated from the world, showing how disease eradication can happen and why it is so difficult to achieve.

options.label: B
options.text: The story of a disease that was cured, showing how medical workers sought to treat diseases or cure them.

options.label: C
options.text: The story of a disease that was discovered, showing how vaccination enhanced the potential to prevent people from contracting illnesses.

options.label: D
options.text: The story of a disease that was eliminated from a single country, showing how health officials realized that eradicating it worldwide was within reach.

multiple-choice.question: What was the devastating impact of smallpox?

options.label: A
options.text: It killed up to 10% of its victims and often left survivors with minor scars.

options.label: B
options.text: It killed up to 30% of its victims and often left survivors with life-long disfiguring scars.

options.label: C
options.text: It killed up to 50% of its victims and often left survivors with minor scars.

options.label: D
options.text: It killed up to 70% of its victims and often left survivors with life-long disfiguring scars.

multiple-choice.question: What was the strategy used to stop the spread of smallpox?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaccinating all people in a region to prevent further transmission.

options.label: B
options.text: Seeking out infected individuals, isolating them, and vaccinating their contacts to prevent further transmission.

options.label: C
options.text: Treating infected individuals with medication to cure the disease.

options.label: D
options.text: Using a combination of vaccination and medication to prevent and cure the disease.

multiple-choice.question: Why was smallpox an ideal candidate for eradication?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it could survive in animal carriers.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it had a long incubation period.

options.label: C
options.text: Because humans are essential to the smallpox lifecycle, so breaking the chain of human to human transmission causes the virus to die out.

options.label: D
options.text: Because there was no effective intervention to stop the virus from spreading.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the smallpox eradication effort?

options.label: A
options.text: Smallpox was eliminated from a single country.

options.label: B
options.text: Smallpox was eliminated from most industrialized countries.

options.label: C
options.text: Smallpox was declared eradicated in 1980, saving approximately 40 million lives over the following two decades.

options.label: D
options.text: Smallpox was declared eradicated in 1990, saving approximately 20 million lives over the following decades.

multiple-choice.question: What are the criteria applied to determine whether other diseases can be similarly eliminated?

options.label: A
options.text: The same criteria used to determine whether a disease is a major public health threat.

options.label: B
options.text: The criteria of whether a disease has a cure or can be treated with medication.

options.label: C
options.text: The criteria of whether a disease can be transmitted from person to person.

options.label: D
options.text: The criteria of whether humans are essential to the disease lifecycle, so breaking the chain of human to human transmission causes the disease to die out.

multiple-choice.question: What has been the progress made towards eradicating guinea worm disease?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of cases has increased by 50% over the past decade.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of cases has decreased by 50% over the past decade.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of cases has decreased by 90% over the past decade, simply by use of water filters.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of cases has remained the same over the past decade.

multiple-choice.question: What has been the impact of vaccination for polio?

options.label: A
options.text: It has prevented 10 million cases of paralysis and 200,000 deaths since 1988.

options.label: B
options.text: It has prevented 13 million cases of paralysis and 650,000 deaths since 1988.

options.label: C
options.text: It has prevented 20 million cases of paralysis and 1 million deaths since 1988.

options.label: D
options.text: It has prevented 30 million cases of paralysis and 2 million deaths since 1988.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of disease eradication?

options.label: A
options.text: To eliminate a specific disease from a single country.

options.label: B
options.text: To eliminate a specific disease from most industrialized countries.

options.label: C
options.text: To eliminate a specific disease from the entire world, as well as all future generations of humanity.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the number of cases of a specific disease.

multiple-choice.question: Why is disease eradication an important public health effort?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it benefits only local populations.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it benefits all of humanity and challenges us to work together as a global community.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a costly and time-consuming process.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not effective in preventing the spread of disease.
